captions.text:
-There are 10 types of
people in the world.

Those who understand binary,
and those who don't.

MATT PARKER: OK, it doesn't
really work when it's said.

But written down, the
joke kind of holds.

Because if I do a 1 and
then a 0, that looks
like the number 10.

Because you expect it to be
a normal base 10 number.

However, if this is in binary,
then this is our units column.
That's our twos column.

And so this actually equals
2 in base 10.

And so you expect it to
be 10, but it's not.
It's 2, and that's the joke.

There are actually two
types of people.

Those who knew this was binary,
and those who didn't.

-There are 10 types of
people in the world.

Those who understand binary,
those who don't, and those who

didn't expect this joke
to be in base 3.

MATT PARKER: OK, good point,
because I guess you--
OK, so it depends on the base.

So if you've got 10, but this
time it's in base 3, then now

you've got a units column, and
then a threes column, and then
nines, and so on.

And so that in normal numbers
would be 3 in base 10.

And so the same 1 and 0 in
a different base mean 3.
Hence the three categories.

-There are 10 types of
people in the world.

Those who understand binary,
those who don't, and--

MATT PARKER: Look, you can
generalize it to any base, OK?

10 in base b is going to
equal b in base 10, OK?

There's an infinite set
of these jokes.
Cut it out.

-There are 10 types of
people in the world.

Those who understand
hexadecimal, and F the rest.

MATT PARKER: OK, I give it to
you, that one is actually
quite funny.

Because now in hexadecimal,
which is base 16--

10 in base 16 still does mean
there are 16 types of people.

And so there's the one category
of people who

understand hexadecimal,
base 16.

But then the remaining
15 in hexadecimal--

15 is just the letter F. And so
when they say F the rest,

they're saying 15
are the rest.

Or I guess the joke is the
double meaning, where if you

just say F in a sentence, it
means you're implying--
uh, fools.

You're saying they're very
foolish, all the people who
don't understand hexadecimal.

-Why do mathematicians confuse
Halloween and Christmas?
Because Oct 31 equals Dec 25.

MATT PARKER: OK, so the
joke here is that Oct
31 equals Dec 25.

And the surface reading is that
this stands for October,
and this stands for December.
But it doesn't.

Oct can stand for the eighth
thing, because October is the
eighth month in the--

it was until Julius Caesar
messed with it.

And Dec used to be the 10th
month, blah, blah, blah.

So anyway, instead of using
these as months, you can use
Oct to mean base 8.

So instead of 31 being in our
normal base 10 setup, if we

put it into base 8, you
have a units column.
You have an eights column.

And so you've now got one
unit and three 8's.

And three 8's is 24, plus
a single unit equals 25.

And so 31 in base 8 equals 25
in base 10, which is why one

equals the other, and
why a mathematician
would confuse them.

BRADY HARAN: This video was
supported by audible.com.

And if you'd like to download
one of their 100,000 titles

for free, go to
audible.com/numberphile.

I actually sampled the product
myself in the last few weeks.

I downloaded a couple of
mountaineering books while I
was holidaying in Nepal.
I love books about mountains.
These are the two I chose.
They were both excellent.

And it was actually really good
fun to be walking through

the mountains while listening to
the book, having it sort of
inside my head.

So I recommend those two as
possible ones when you
download your free one.

That's audible.com/numberphile,
and

thanks to them for supporting
our videos.
[LAUGHTER]

comments.author: mimi A

comments.text:
Actually, you really can't generalize that first joke to any base.  The 
only one of that set that makes any sense is the first one.  Saying there 
are 10 types of people in the world: those who understand binary, those who 
don't, and those who didn't expect this joke to be in base 3 doesn't make 
sense.  That is saying that the group who didn't expect it to be in base 3 
are distinct from those who do and don't understand binary, which can't be 
the case.  Also, how does it follow that you can do any number of jokes 
like this?  What would be the base 4 joke?  There are 10 types of people in 
the world: those who understand binary, those who don't, those who expected 
this joke to be in base 3, and those who didn't expect this joke to be in 
base 4?  Nah, I don't think so.

Also, I swear that brown paper is the back side of that maroon Ikea brand 
Christmas wrapping paper.  Looks just like it.﻿

Random fact for you: in the periodic table, Ho (Holmium, element 67) stands 
next to Er (Erbium, element 68). These elements create the word Hoer, which 
is the Dutch word for 'whore'. And it's quite coincidental that the element 
after erbium is element 69

comments.text:
I don't think misunderstanding complex numbers qualifies somebody as an 
idiot. Also you don't have base i because i is it's own number line. You 
can have an complex number in any base. How could you write 10 in base i? 
You can't break 10 down into parts divisible by i and parts not divisible 
by i because there are no i components (well technically 10 + 0i but that 
means all numbers on the real number line are not representable)

comments.author: raditzan

comments.text:
+raditzan  Okay, so a base number must be a positive whole number. of 2 or 
higher.  So my point stands. Infinity itself is a symbol,  not a whole 
number so it can't be a base.  A natural number is a counting number and it 
must also have a successor.  Does infinity have a successor  ∞+1 does not 
count.
comments.author: Vanewolf29

comments.text:
+Vanewolf29 An Integer is an element of the Integer set, which is the set 
of all whole numbers, we know that there can't be negative bases. You could 
have said the base b ∈ [2,∞)
Or
∃b∈ℤ, b is a valid base
comments.author: raditzan

comments.text:
+raditzan  and integer is a whole number that can be written without 
fractions which is the same basic thing you said. A natural number though 
always has a successor. Does infinity have a successor?

comments.author: P. De Rop

comments.text:
+coastersplus You can't have an infinite amount of something. Also saying 
you have an infinite amount of something is the same as saying I have a 
limitless amount of something, or an unmeasurable amount, one that does not 
end. This is why infinities do not exist in the real world. By the way, you 
can have bases that are a googolplex, or a googolplex^googolplex or 
googolplex^googolplex^googolplex, but not infinity.
comments.author: raditzan

comments.author: Cyberw4y

comments.text:
In base infinity, there would just be a new character for every next 
number, and the next column (in base 10 the 10's column) would never be 
needed. It's a possible system, but an impractical one, as every time you 
want a new number someone would have to make a new symbol for it. In the 
end they would just make the basic numbers (e.g. 1, 5, 10, 50...) and add 
them together, like the Romans did, e.g. XV = 10 + 5.

be possible. And have you ever tried understand spawn rates and drop tables 
in Minecraft or the chance that one block would come up next versus another 
one?  Guess what the computer scientists and programmers had to turn to 
algorithms developed by guess who? Mathematicians... so.. without the 
Mathematician you ate for breakfast this morning.. well do you really want 
to delve into the statistical probability that the next great find in 
computer science will be found tomorrow or a month from now. Sigh... 
Computer scientists have such looping logic.

comments.text:
although, i suppose if you assume that those who didn't expect base 3 are 
implicitly all in the group that understand binary, then there are indeed 
only 4 groups.
comments.author: rhiiazami

comments.text:
if you allow for overlap between the groups and insist that those who fall 
between 2 groups or into 2 groups are their own group, then there are 
actually 5 groups. those who understand binary, those who don't, those who 
didn't expect base 3, those who don't understand binary and didn't expect 
base 3, and those who understand binary and didn't expect base 3. 
admittedly the 4th group there is a tad unlikely since they may not 
necessarily know what it is they aren't expecting, but possible.
